scenarios.title: Our Community News

listening.receptive: Recognize the main ideas of longer conversational exchanges.
listening.interactive: Respond to questions about requesting information.

reading.reading1: Identify specific information from fictional short texts.
reading.reading2: Identify the sequence of events in simple stories.

speaking.productive: Describe past events using simple past forms.
speaking.interactive: Ask and answer questions about community events.

writing.productive: Write short news-style paragraphs with basic structure.
writing.interactive: Collaborate to draft headlines and captions for a class newsletter.

mediation.text: Simplify event flyers for peers, highlighting key details with visuals.
mediation.concept: Use diagrams to explain concepts to peers.

grammar: Simple past (e.g., 'We visited the park.')
Wh-questions (e.g., 'What happened at the fair?')
There was/were (e.g., 'There were many people.')

pragmatic: Reporting news: 'Last week, our school had a fair.'
Asking for details: 'What happened at the parade?'
sociolinguistic: Respectful reporting: Using neutral and factual language when sharing community news.

assessment_ideas: Observe student participation in mock interviews about school events.
Review school or community news articles with clear sequence and past tense.
Assess simplified flyers with key details and visuals.

scenarios.title: Keeping Our Communities Clean
themes: We Should Clean the Classroom on Friday.
Who Will Bring the Cleaning Supplies?

listening.receptive: Identify specific details in spoken announcements.
listening.interactive: Interpret audio clips from class lessons to support class discussions.

reading.reading1: Follow written instructions for community-based tasks.
reading.reading2: Identify main ideas in short informational texts about community actions.

speaking.productive: Give instructions using imperatives and modals.
speaking.interactive: Participate in group discussions on community actions.

writing.productive: Write a simple interpretation of common texts with visual aids.
writing.interactive: Facilitate a group project discussion by writing prompts and showing visuals.

mediation.communication: Use visual aids and simple phrases to clarify project instructions for peers.

grammar: Imperatives (e.g., 'Bring a trash bag.')
Modals (e.g., 'We should organize the desks.')
Future with 'will' (e.g., 'I will clean the windows.')

pragmatic: Making suggestions: 'We should clean the desks.'
Assigning tasks: 'You will sweep the floor.'
sociolinguistic: Participating in group discussions on community actions.

assessment_ideas: Review community clean-up plans with imperatives and modals.
Observe poster presentations promoting school clean-up day.
Assess use of visual aids to clarify instructions during group tasks.

scenarios.title: Our Local Library
themes: How Do I Use the Library?

listening.receptive: Understand basic information in library-related announcements.
listening.interactive: Ask follow-up questions about library procedures.

reading.reading1: Locate specific information in library catalogs or signs.
reading.reading2: Follow step-by-step instructions for using library resources.

speaking.productive: Describe library resources and their uses.

writing.productive: Write short instructions for using a library resource.
writing.interactive: Create labels or signs for a simulated library corner.

mediation.text: Explain how to use library resources.
mediation.concept: Use diagrams to explain library systems (e.g., book categories).

grammar: How to + verb (e.g., 'How to find a book')
Prepositions of place (e.g., 'The shelf is next to the desk.')
Can for ability (e.g., 'You can borrow three books.')

pragmatic: Asking for help: 'Where can I find books about animals?'
Giving directions: 'The fiction section is on the left.'
sociolinguistic: Following library norms: Using quiet tones and polite expressions.

assessment_ideas: Observe library scavenger hunt participation.
Review library resource guides with clear steps.
Assess digital library maps with labeled sections.

scenarios.title: Our Classroom News
themes: I Will Write the Article About Our School Trip.
We Need Pictures for the Classroom Newsletter.

listening.receptive: Follow multi-step instructions for collaborative writing tasks.
listening.interactive: Clarify meanings during peer editing sessions.

reading.reading1: Identify main ideas and supporting details in class-written texts.
reading.reading2: Edit peers’ writing for coherence and basic grammar.

speaking.productive: Present news orally with clear sequencing.
speaking.interactive: Collaborate on writing roles (writer, editor, presenter).

writing.productive: Write short news-style paragraphs about class events.
writing.interactive: Collaborate to create a classroom newsletter.

mediation.communication: Assist peers in organizing ideas for writing.
mediation.text: Summarize classmates’ ideas in simplified notes.

grammar: Future with 'will' (e.g., 'I will write the article.')
Past simple for events (e.g., 'We visited the museum.')
Present continuous for current actions (e.g., 'We are editing the photos.')

pragmatic: Assigning writing roles: 'You will take photos.'
Reporting events: 'Last Tuesday, we went to the zoo.'
sociolinguistic: Collaborating respectfully in team writing tasks.

assessment_ideas: Review classroom newsletters with clear headlines and photos.
Observe script performances of school event reports.
Assess peer feedback during editing sessions.

scenarios.title: Our Amazing Community
themes: This School Has Been Here a Long Time!

listening.receptive: Determine the gist of simple stories or reports related to familiar subjects.
listening.interactive: Ask questions to clarify understanding of local history.

reading.reading1: Identify key facts in short texts about community history.
reading.reading2: Compare past and present descriptions in informational texts.

speaking.productive: Describe places using comparatives and superlatives.
speaking.interactive: Share personal connections to community landmarks.

writing.productive: Write short descriptive paragraphs about local places.
writing.interactive: Contribute to a collaborative community brochure.

mediation.concept: Link historical events to current community features.
mediation.communication: Explain why a place is important using personal and historical reasons.

grammar: Comparatives and superlatives (e.g., 'This school is older than that one.')
Present perfect for experiences (e.g., 'This school has been here for 50 years.')
There is/are (e.g., 'There is a park near my house.')

pragmatic: Describing places: 'This park is the most beautiful in town.'
Expressing pride: 'I’m proud of my school.'
sociolinguistic: Showing respect for community heritage and diversity.

assessment_ideas: Review community brochures with descriptions and historical facts.
Observe presentations about local landmarks.
Assess use of comparatives in written descriptions.

scenarios.title: Our Weather Report
themes: Today's Weather Will Be Sunny with Some Rain Later.
How Will the Weather Change Tomorrow?

listening.receptive: Identify specific details in spoken announcements.
listening.interactive: Predict outcomes based on weather information.

reading.reading1: Interpret weather symbols and short forecasts.
reading.reading2: Extract specific data from weather charts.

speaking.productive: Describe current and future weather conditions.
speaking.interactive: Give recommendations based on weather (e.g., 'Bring an umbrella.').

writing.productive: Write short weather forecasts using future tense.
writing.interactive: Create a class weather log with daily entries.

mediation.concept: Summarize weather-related concepts for classmates by combining words and diagrams.
mediation.text: Simplify weather forecasts using visuals and key words.

grammar: Future with 'will' (e.g., 'It will rain tomorrow.')
Going to for predictions (e.g., 'It’s going to be sunny.')
Modal 'should' for advice (e.g., 'You should wear a jacket.')

pragmatic: Making predictions: 'It’s going to be cloudy.'
Giving advice: 'You should take your raincoat.'
sociolinguistic: Using weather language to plan and care for others.

assessment_ideas: Observe weather report presentations with forecasts and advice.
Review digital weather logs with daily predictions.
Assess use of diagrams (e.g., water cycle) to explain weather concepts.

scenarios.title: Our Changing Forests

listening.receptive: Understand main ideas in environmental talks.
listening.interactive: Discuss solutions to simple environmental problems.

reading.reading1: Identify cause-and-effect relationships in short environmental texts.

speaking.productive: Explain simple environmental actions using modals.

writing.productive: Write short persuasive messages about conservation.
writing.interactive: Create recycling instructions for the school.

mediation.text: Simplify recycling instructions using symbols and short phrases.
mediation.concept: Use visuals to explain why forests are important.

grammar: Modals for obligation and advice (e.g., 'We must protect trees.', 'You should recycle.')
Present simple for facts (e.g., 'Trees give us oxygen.')
Imperatives for instructions (e.g., 'Separate your trash.')

pragmatic: Instructing: 'Put paper in the blue bin.'
sociolinguistic: Discussing environmental responsibility as a community value.

assessment_ideas: Review recycling campaign posters with clear instructions.
Observe debates on eco-actions (e.g., 'Should we use plastic bags?').
Assess simplified recycling guides with symbols and modals.

scenarios.title: The Talents Around Us
themes: Who Will Perform in the Fiestas Patrias Activities?
I Will Play the Drums in the Parade.

listening.receptive: Identify specific details in narratives that include expressions of feelings and attitudes.
listening.interactive: Recognize the main ideas of the conversation when interacting in group discussions.

reading.reading1: Understand simple event programs or performance schedules.
reading.reading2: Identify roles and responsibilities in group activity descriptions.

speaking.productive: Describe personal talents and future plans for events.
speaking.interactive: Invite others to participate in community performances.

writing.productive: Write short event invitations or performance descriptions.
writing.interactive: Collaborate on a program for a school or community event.

mediation.communication: Explain roles in a performance to peers using gestures and simple terms.
mediation.text: Summarize event details for absent classmates.

grammar: Future with 'will' (e.g., 'I will play the drums.')
Can for ability (e.g., 'She can dance very well.')
Wh-questions (e.g., 'Who will sing in the parade?')

pragmatic: Expressing plans: 'I will play the drums.'
sociolinguistic: Celebrating cultural events with respect and enthusiasm.

assessment_ideas: Review event programs with clear roles and schedules.
Observe talent showcase presentations.
Assess invitations with future tense and polite language.
